COPIM’s Experimental Publishing group is delighted to announce our #ExperimentalBooks online conference "Experimental Books – Re-imagining Scholarly Publishing", taking place on the 20/02, 09/03, & 13/03/2023 #OAbooks

REGISTER NOW:
https://experimentalbooks.pubpub.org/

This three-part conference - including talks, roundtables, and workshops - will discuss alternative publishing options for the humanities by showcasing some of the experiments that are currently taking place in the realm of academic book publishing. It aims to inspire authors, publishers, technology developers and others, to (continue to) speculate on new collaborative futures for open humanities research and publication. It also aims to discuss how these book experiments could sit within more standardised or established workflows for print and online book production, dissemination, and preservation.

title: Tools such as ChatGPT threaten transparent science; here are our ground rules for their use

last_post.content:
#Nature adopts two rules for the use of #LLMs like #ChatGPT.
https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-023-00191-1

"First, no LLM tool will be accepted as a credited author on a research paper…Any attribution of authorship carries with it accountability for the work & AI tools cannot take such responsibility.

Second, researchers using LLM tools should document this use in the methods or acknowledgements sections."

title: Deleting DMs from Twitter using the GDPR

last_post.content:
Months back I suggested people use data protection rights to ask Twitter to erase their DMs, as deleting them manually does not remove them from the server (https://michae.lv/deleting-dms-from-twitter/). Twitter sent back an illegal response to all who asked, ignoring the Q & instead a pro forma "Here's how you delete your account!".

I complained to the ICO & Irish DPC. ICO wrote a letter to T telling them to comply within 14 days, but still nothing.

I know others have complained — have you heard back from DPAs?

title: New AI classifier for indicating AI-written text

last_post.content:
OpenAI released a tool which purports to detect AI-generated text. At the highest end of detection, it labels text "possibly" or "likely" AI-generated. 21% of human-written text falls under "possibly" and 9% of "likely" does. That's 3 in 10 students being defamed and/or harmed.

Just like other providers of academic surveillance software, OpenAI states that their detector "should not be used as a primary decision-making tool".

It will be, though. And harm will follow.

https://openai.com/blog/new-ai-classifier-for-indicating-ai-written-text/

title: Black Americans Are Much More Likely to Face Tax Audits, Study Finds

last_post.content:
A new paper by Prof Dan Ho of Stanford shows racial bias in tax audits - black Americans are 3-5x more likely to be audited

I'm saddened, but not especially surprised: https://www.nytimes.com/2023/01/31/us/politics/black-americans-irs-tax-audits.html

Janet Holtzblatt & I wrote a Tax Policy Center primer about the emerging use of machine learning by IRS for audit selection.

We raised these specific concerns, especially that lower audits rates and reduced IRS budget would increase the likelihood of bias: https://www.urban.org/sites/default/files/2022-06/Machine%20Learning%20and%20Tax%20Enforcement.pdf

title: Functional Programming in Scala, Second Edition

last_post.content:
The genius of #Scala's "Red Book" is that it explains very generic and hard to understand concepts in simple and very elegant code. And how many #Haskell books have you seen implementing their own `IO`?

It's not the code that library authors write, but gosh, it's the code we want to write. And #Scala is such a good language for learning #FP ❤️

If you want to learn functional programming, there aren't that many good books, and this is one of them...

title: Company Offers to Sell Computers Back to San Benito Schools

last_post.content:
Good grief...

San Benito school district (you may recognize the name from the recent disclosure of the #ransomware incident involving #Karakurt) sold thousands of district computers and devices at an online auction in July.

An auction company bought about 700 computers and it wasn't long before they discovered school district data -- employee data and student data -- on at least 11 of the hard drives.

So they contacted the district who tried to buy the computers back. The district doesn't want to pay what the buyer is asking and the buyer also refuses to sign a nondisclosure agreement.

Other than that, everything's just hunkydory....

Read more at GovTech, while @douglevin updates the k12six map with this one....

https://www.govtech.com/education/k-12/company-offers-to-sell-computers-back-to-san-benito-schools

although now long forgotten as a historical curio of 2000s web idealism, the OLPC "One Laptop Per Child" project attempted to produce a low-cost, high-reliability laptop suitable for kids in low-income environments.

one of the upshots of the program was that SimCity was open-sourced for the OLPC XO-1 computer, and it was included on every machine. this little article by don hopkins does a great job of tracing its history through Sun Microsystems.
